definition: to pick up
to hold/to seize/to catch/to apprehend/to take/(used in the same way as 把[ba3]: to mark the following noun as a direct object)
old variant of 拿[na2]
variant of 拿[na2]

to rise/to raise/to get up/to set out/to start/to appear/to launch/to initiate (action)/to draft/to establish/to get (from a depot or counter)/verb suffix, to start/starting from (a time, place, price etc)/classifier for occurrences or unpredictable events: case, instance/classifier for groups: batch, group

sentences.english: Even now during my part-time, I drew some goldfish for pleasure.
sentences.chinese: 闲暇时光有时会拿起画笔，画金鱼玩。

sentences.english: He carefully picked up his pole. He felt his heart pounding.
sentences.chinese: 他小心翼翼地拿起撑竿，只觉得心怦怦在跳。

sentences.english: Sara grabs a hole-punch and smashes the glass of a nearby cabinet.
sentences.chinese: Sara拿起一个打孔机，打碎了附近壁柜的玻璃。

sentences.english: Ashley leaves. Scarlett throws a vase to the wall in anger.
sentences.chinese: 艾希礼离开了，愤怒之中思嘉拿起一个花瓶向墙砸去。

sentences.english: Feliks gently lifted the bottle of nitroglycerine out of the sink.
sentences.chinese: 费利克斯轻轻地从水池中拿起那瓶硝化甘油。

sentences.english: Daddy picked up the paddle and started spanking Melody's bare bottom with the gentlest spanks possible.
sentences.chinese: 乔希拿起扁板，开始尽量轻的拍打米洛蒂的光屁股。

sentences.english: Each picked up a, that the taste is changed.
sentences.chinese: 每拿起一本，那味道就变了。

sentences.english: Brendan drained the rest of his glass and looked back into Tom's face, which seemed more serious now, his lips closed in a flat line.
sentences.chinese: 丹拿起杯子一饮而尽，回头看看汤姆的脸。

sentences.english: The judge took up the gavel with solemnity.
sentences.chinese: 法官严肃地拿起了小木槌。

sentences.english: There have been many people who took up meaningful hobbies in their advanced age.
sentences.chinese: 曾有不少人拿起他们年事已高有意义的业余爱好。

sentences.english: Ben picked up a notebook and started towrite Felicity a note.
sentences.chinese: 本拿起记事簿，开始给费莉希蒂写纸条。

sentences.english: Simon picked the toy up and squeezed it.
sentences.chinese: 西蒙拿起这只玩具紧紧地把它握紧。

sentences.english: Absurdly I held it and weighed it in my hand, to give myself courage.
sentences.chinese: 我可笑地拿起枪，在手里掂掂，替自己壮胆。

sentences.english: I picked up a knife, on the whole front of the microfilm into the world's gone.
sentences.chinese: 一拿起刻刀，整个人就钻进眼前那个缩微世界里去了。

sentences.english: Sometimes life hits you in the head with a brick.
sentences.chinese: 虽然命运有时候会拿起板砖，猛拍你的脑袋。

sentences.english: She picked up a new magazine with her free hand.
sentences.chinese: 她用空着的一只手拿起一本新杂志。

definition: to take (sth proffered)
on hand/at hand
to heave/to lift/to raise up/to uphold
to pick up
to fish out/to take out (from a pocket, bag etc)
to lay down/to put down/to let go of/to relinquish/to set aside/to lower (the blinds etc)
conveniently/without extra trouble/while doing it/in passing
to pick up (from the ground with one's hands)
to cast or put aside/to forget for a while
to take out/to put out/to provide/to put forward (a proposal)/to come up with (evidence)
table/desk/CL:張|张[zhang1],套[tao4]
easily/without trouble/while one is at it/in passing/handy
to get up/to leave/to set forth
to move back and forth/to fiddle with
to throw down/to drop (bomb)
to stand up
